original_text.text:
In the quiet solitude of a local library, Philip is found shockingly murdered with a barbed wire, leaving Detective Winston with the arduous task of sifting truth from alibis of the two main suspects, Hugo and Maria.

Winston's mind was buzzing during the ride to the local hair salon, a tragic incident sinking his spirits. Philip, a library frequenter, was dead, with dire circumstances suggesting a gruesome murder. The weapon, a coil of barbed wire, unusual for sure. As he walked into the salon, he saw a middle-aged woman, Maria with a multitude of barbed hairpins reflecting ominously under the lights. She was working away with a pair of scissors, her nimble fingers managing both the razor and the various hairpins with the dexterity of an artist.

"Maria?" Winston asked.

Caught off guard, Maria looked up, her eyes wide in surprise. "Yes, detective, can I help you with something?" she answered, never pausing her delicate dance of grooming. She clicked her scissors, moved on to her razor, then her infamous collection of barbed hairpins, all with the practiced ease of someone in her profession for a long time. 

"I hear you've been doing this for over fifteen years?" he asked, partially making small talk, partially feeling out the woman in front of him.

"Sixteen years, next Tuesday." She replied, her gaze deliberately focused on her current client's head. 

"Quite a long time..." Winston said, thoughtful. "You ever do hair for a fellow called Philip?"

Maria paused for a moment, her eyes downcast. "Yes, I did his hair once. He's the one found in the library, right?"

"Yes," Winston nodded, "I heard about your usual evening strolls to the library. The one open late till 10 pm?"

"Yeah, it's quiet, peaceful. They don't mind if I bring my coffee inside. I even have a key, just in case I lose track of time and it's closing," Maria disclosed.

"I see. How about Robert? Phillip's fiance. He been here, recently?" Winston changed the subject.

Maria swallowed and cleared her throat, stepping away from her customer to face Winston. "Yes, he came... to talk." 

"To talk about the wedding, or about that time in high school where you confessed your love to him before he proposed to Philip?" Winston probed.

Maria averted her eyes, "About the wedding... but, yes, we also brought up the past. I've been in love with Robert since high school, and I've been secretly carrying that love for years, you know."

Winston observed Maria. Things certainly aren't always as they seem, he thought, as she returned to her client, her barbed hairpins dancing in the slightly unsettling light. The fact that the time of Philip's death aligned eerily with Maria's usual library visit was an added layer of unease. "Well, Robert's supposed to marry Philip soon, isn't he?" 

"Yes, but things aren't always as they seem, detective." Maria's voice held an edge as she responded, her gaze being both hurt yet defiant, hinting at a deeper tale yet to unravel.

Blowing off steam, jumping from coffee shop to coffee shop, Winston was back on track, unanswered questions regarding Philip's mysterious murder bouncing in his mind. Known for his capacity for violence to get what he wanted, Philip had a reputation; ironically, barbed wire, his common form of conflict resolution, had been the weapon.

The detectives at the precinct were all a twitter about the eccentric sound technician, Hugo. Out of all potential suspects they'd drawn in, one thing about Hugo was blinking on Winston's radar. Not once had any colleague, friend or customer ever been invited to his personal studio where Hugo spent most of his time. The man was protective of his private space, it seemed. 

"I'm detouring to Hugo's office," Winston informed his partner as he made a left turn.

The professional layout of Hugo's studio stood testament to his skills. Winston noticed the different categories of wires neatly stowed away, labeled by type. Spools of common wires were neatly packed, then his gaze floated towards an unusual collection of unique wires, barbed wire included, labeled 'personal collection'. He stroked one with his gloved fingers, lost in thought.

"Hugo," Winston called for his attention, "This is some impressive collection. Not everyone works with barbed wire in a sound system, huh?" Hugo's smile was gentle, "I just like to keep my wire knowledge versatile," he shrugged.

"I heard you missed out on this year's industry conference," Winston inquired casually. 

"Yeah. Conferences are not my cup of tea," Hugo chuckled, "Too much show and too little know. I prefer focusing on the actual job, here in my studio."

Casual chat moved reflective as Winston asked about Philip, "What about Philip? Ever get into a formal tussle with him?" Hugo's rifle through a box of cables paused, "No direct confrontation, sir, but I was an unfortunate audience to threats he made to my brother over a phone call. Nastiest conversation ever."

Winston nodded, taking in the distraught sound engineer before himself. Hugo's brother owed a significant amount to Philip, everyone and their nephew knew that. It had been no blind gamble, but rather a bet gone awry. It had complicated Hugo's personal dynamics, certainly. Especially so since no one saw Hugo at the annual company holiday party. Usually a regular, Hugo's absence sent alerts.

Duty kept Hugo traveling between different venues for sound gigs, with a vast array of tools tagging all along, wires included, also, wires very similar to the ones found at Philip's crime scene. Winston mulled over this kaleidoscope of details, knowing well the devil lay in their details, as he drove back to the precinct.

original_text.text:
In the chilling aftermath of Iris' untimely death by a stun gun in a lonely parked car, seasoned detective Winston finds himself waist-deep in a web of intrigue involving two prime suspects, Paige and Alicia.

Winston pinched the bridge of his nose, tired from a long night of pouring over evidence. In his hands, he held a stack of emails, one of which indicated that Paige had set up a meeting with Iris on the day of her death. He had also discovered a certificate amongst Paige's belongings that showed she had completed a self-defense course complete with stun gun training. He also noticed that as Iris's direct subordinate, Paige was next in line to lead the company, particularly since Iris didn't have any family members who could inherit the role. Additionally, he held company accounts that show a gradual decline in profits, a likely result of Iris's stubbornness to cut staff numbers and her constant investment in unsuccessful projects. 

An email, a key to Iris's car found among Paige's belongings confirming her access, a timestamp, and a set of scorched fingerprints were all he had. Adding to this, CCTV footage from the company consistently showed Iris's car parked at their workplace confirming her regular presence. Straightening up in his chair, he got up, stretched, and went to interview his next suspect on the list - Paige, who had recently been seen on CCTV footage purchasing a stun gun.

Making his way out of the police station, Winston found himself in a tall glass building, home to the company that Iris had managed. Upon entering, he confirmed with a coworker that the last person to see Iris alive was indeed Paige, taking Iris into a meeting. 

"Detective Winston? Welcome," said Paige. 

Winston glanced at the trash next to her desk, spotting a receipt from the stun gun shop that coincided with the CCTV footage and asked, "Have you been keeping up with your stun gun training?"

Paige looked taken aback, but answered, "Yes, I find it essential. Safety matters."

The detective nodded, an unease creeping up on him as he thought about the circumstances surrounding Iris's death, wondering whether the profits would rise once again now that Paige was stepping up.

Winston took a sip of his cold coffee as he lay his eyes on the glossy wedding album of Iris. Alicia must have done a flawless job for a wedding in this grandeurs scale.

He turned off the city streets, pulling into a small car park next to a utility store. Alicia was there, in the shop that sold stun guns among other things, surrounded by the cluttered mess of wires and bolts. Tagged along in her workspace was her office, filled with numerous taxidermy pufferfish that were unusually large and placed strategically for utmost visibility. As the owner and wedding planner, Alicia had to keep track of everything. Winston took a mental note of her electrical engineering degree framed on the wall.

"Alicia," Winston intoned as she finally looked up from her workbench.

"Detective," She greeted him coolly, "Here to pick a stun gun?"

"Actually, I'm looking into a case," Winston said, sliding the crime scene photos across the counter.

Alicia's eyes scanned them but she said nothing. Her hand didn't shake even when he laid out the receipt his team had found in her apartment. A receipt for a stun gun purchased a week ago.

"So, tell me about this," Winston motioned towards the pufferfish on her desk. Alicia’s eyes lit up as she started passionately rambling about the intricacies of it.

Winston picked up her laptop, left casually open on police databases. The business' financials weren't good - she was operating at a loss and had to borrow heavily from nontraditional lenders. This major wedding event must have been a boost for her, financially speaking.

Winston got up, preparing to leave. "Your work here, it's all very remarkable, Miss Alicia."

"Thank you for your words, detective," she said, her gaze shifting once again to the photographs laid out on the bench. 

Winston had no choice but to leave her to her pufferfish and stun guns. "Take care, Miss Alicia," he said before walking out the door.

"Is there anyone from Iris's family that could take over the company?" he asked his  young assistant who was pouring over police reports in the corner. 

"No, she didn't have any family," the assistant called back. 

As Winston dig deeper into the case, he found that Paige, as Iris's direct subordinate, would be the next in line for company leadership. Questioning her could give him some more perspective. 

He found her sitting in her office, fiddling with a set of keys. He couldn't help but notice she was surrounded by a collection of pens from various meets, a quirk that was both peculiar and endearing. However, his keen eye was caught by a hair tie that was nestled amongst the pens. 

"You pick that up recently?" He chimed, nodding towards the hair tie. Caught off guard, she nodded, "Yes, it was on the floor in the office." Winston just nodded, filing that information away for later. 

Diving into their conversation, Paige admitted that Iris was a dedicated boss, refusing to cut staff numbers and that she kept investing in unsuccessful projects, much to the chagrin of others. Paige admitted to knowing about the company's deteriorating health, given Iris's stubborn management methods, yet, she seemed thoroughly sad about her boss's demise.

Just then, one of Paige's employees entered, looking flustered. "I found something weird," she said, showing Winston something that looked like a keyhole behind a movable panel in Paige’s desk... a stark contrast to the otherwise meticulous space around them. His curiosity piqued, Winston thanked them and left with a promise for further communication. 

Walking around the company's parking lot, he noticed Iris's car often in the frame of the CCTV footage. A coworker who was pulling out of the lot told Winston about seeing Iris the night she died.

"Saw her going into that meeting with Paige; she looked real tense, " the coworker indicated a glass cabin that evidently served as the meeting room.

Winston decided to question Paige further. "Do you have a key to Iris's car by any chance?" A flicker of surprise flashed across Paige's face as she answered, "Yes, I do. Is something wrong, Detective?" 

"Not at all, just following up on some leads. Thank you for your time, Ma'am," he assured her before making his way back to his car.

Winston flicked through the paperwork once more, using the dull humming coming from the precinct to focus his thoughts. In front of him, there was a landscape photo featuring Alicia in action, surrounded by a sea of flower crowns and women in long dresses. She was a wedding planner, overseeing all the details, including the transportation.

He looked deeper into the photo and noticed an electronic store across the street, where a store associate had reported Alicia making a purchase. Winston remembered speaking to that associate, who confirmed Alicia bought a stun gun there. This was a store that also sold stun guns, which had recently been purchased by Alicia. It confirmed what he was told, she did work in such a shop part-time. 

Winston glanced out his window, thinking pensive thoughts. The wedding required Iris’s car. It was Alicia’s job to ensure the car was used appropriately during the grand event. It certainly was a grand event, and it was a big payday for Alicia’s business.

“Detective Winston, we have new documents for you.” An officer placed a file on his desk with a 'thump'. Financial statements. Alicia’s business wasn’t doing well. In fact, it was operating at a loss.

Heaving a sigh, Winston packed the files into his case. He made his way to Alicia’s apartment. As he walked through the entrance, his gaze fell upon a ledge where the mail was neatly stacked. He could see a receipt peeping out. With a pair of thin gloves, he picked it up. A receipt from the shop. The same shop where Alicia was seen buying a stun gun.

He knew Alicia had studied electrical engineering during her college years. She would definitely know how to use it. His mobile device buzzed then, alerting him to a new email. It contained background info on Alicia's financials. A different kind of record... Alicia had been borrowing heavily, and mostly not from banks. Nontraditional lenders... not an ideal situation to be in.

Stepping outside, Winston lit a cigarette, his hand steady, but mind racing. But then, his phone buzzed again with a new update from precinct. There were multiple eyewitnesses who reported seeing Alicia and Iris together just before the incident. The last time they'd been seen together, was leaving the wedding rehearsal. The same evening when the incident happened.

“Just the facts, Winston. Just the facts,” he said to himself, squashing out the cigarette and returning inside. There was more to uncover, and Alicia just happened to be at the center of it. Time would reveal the truth.

qna_model.story:
In the chilling aftermath of Iris' untimely death by a stun gun in a lonely parked car, seasoned detective Winston finds himself waist-deep in a web of intrigue involving two prime suspects, Paige and Alicia.

Pulling off his reading glasses, Detective Winston stared in thought at the computer screen. The emails between Iris and Paige showed a scheduled meeting for the day of the murder, with the subject line reading "Company Future" in bold letters, hinting at a discussion of significant importance regarding the company's declining state. He looked over to Iris' company accounts and noticed a fall in profits that had been happening over some time. The company's profits had been in a steady decline for approximately two years before Iris's death, with the most notable drop occurring in the last six months, which coincided with Iris's refusal to cut staff numbers and her continued investment in unsuccessful projects.

"Is there anyone from Iris' family that could take over the company?" he asked his young assistant who was pouring over police reports in the corner.

"No, she didn't have any family," the assistant called back.

As Winston dug deeper into the case, he found that Paige, as Iris' direct subordinate, would be the next in line for company leadership. Besides Paige, there was another potential successor, a man named Ryan, who had been with the company almost as long as Paige but had taken a leave of absence six months prior to Iris's death, making Paige the more immediate and obvious choice for succession. Questioning her could give him some more perspective.

He found her sitting in her office, fiddling with a set of keys. He couldn't help but notice she was surrounded by a collection of pens from various meets, a quirk that was both peculiar and endearing. However, his keen eye was caught by a hair tie that was nestled amongst the pens. The hair tie found on Paige's desk belonged to one of the company's interns, who had been in Paige's office earlier that day discussing a project and must have left it behind, though Detective Winston noted that the intern had long, curly hair, and the tie was designed for straight hair, sparking a minor inconsistency in Paige's initial explanation.

"You pick that up recently?" He chimed, nodding towards the hair tie. Caught off guard, she nodded, "Yes, it was on the floor in the office." Winston just nodded, filing that information away for later.

Diving into their conversation, Paige admitted that Iris was a dedicated boss, refusing to cut staff numbers and that she kept investing in unsuccessful projects, much to the chagrin of others. Iris and Paige had a complex working relationship; while Iris valued Paige's insight and work ethic, making her a direct subordinate and potential successor, Paige often found Iris's management methods outdated and frustrating, leading to tense but respectful interactions between them. Paige admitted to knowing about the company's deteriorating health, given Iris's stubborn management methods, yet, she seemed thoroughly sad about her boss's demise. The unsuccessful projects Iris invested in were primarily related to sustainable energy and green technology, which several board members, including Ryan before his leave, had opposed due to the high upfront costs and uncertain returns, causing significant tension within the company.

Just then, one of Paige's employees entered, looking flustered. "I found something weird," she said, showing Winston something that looked like a keyhole behind a movable panel in Paige's desk, a stark contrast to the otherwise meticulous space around them. The hidden keyhole in Paige's desk unlocked a small compartment where she kept sensitive documents and notes, including observations about the company's financial health and her own plans for restructure should she take over, which she had been compiling over the past year in anticipation of Iris's eventual retirement or departure. His curiosity piqued, Winston thanked them and left with a promise for further communication.

Paige claimed to have been in her office from 2:00 PM to 4:00 PM on the day of the murder, working on reports and occasionally stepping out to discuss ongoing projects with other staff members, though she admitted to taking a short walk around the block at approximately 3:30 PM to clear her head.

Walking around the company's parking lot, he noticed Iris's car often in the frame of the CCTV footage. A coworker who was pulling out of the lot told Winston about seeing Iris the night she died.

"Saw her going into that meeting with Paige; she looked real tense," the coworker indicated a glass cabin that evidently served as the meeting room. There were surveillance cameras near the location where Iris's body was found, but they did not capture the crime itself, only showing Iris's car arriving and leaving the area, with a significant gap in the footage due to a technical issue that occurred around the time of the murder.

Winston decided to question Paige further. "Do you have a key to Iris's car by any chance?" A flicker of surprise flashed across Paige's face as she answered, "Yes, I do. Is something wrong, Detective?"

"Not at all, just following up on some leads. Thank you for your time, Ma'am," he assured her before making his way back to his car.

Winston flicked through the paperwork once more, using the dull humming coming from the precinct to focus his thoughts. In front of him, there was a landscape photo featuring Alicia in action, surrounded by a sea of flower crowns and women in long dresses. She was a wedding planner, overseeing all the details, including the transportation. Iris and Alicia's relationship was strictly professional, having interacted only in the context of the wedding planning, where Iris's car was to be used as part of the procession, though Alicia mentioned that Iris seemed particularly stressed about the event, citing concerns over the company's image and her personal reputation. Iris was not known to have any knowledge of Alicia's financial struggles or her part-time job at the electronic store, as their interactions were limited and focused on the logistics of the wedding.

He looked deeper into the photo and noticed an electronic store across the street, where a store associate had reported Alicia making a purchase. Winston remembered speaking to that associate, who confirmed Alicia bought a stun gun there. This was a store that also sold stun guns, which had recently been purchased by Alicia. It confirmed what he was told, she did work in such a shop part-time. Besides Alicia, who had purchased a stun gun from the electronic store, there were no other individuals known to have had access to the weapon or Iris's car around the time of the murder, though Detective Winston was still investigating potential accomplices or witnesses.

Winston glanced out his window, thinking pensive thoughts. The wedding required Iris's car. It was Alicia's job to ensure the car was used appropriately during the grand event. It certainly was a grand event, and it was a big payday for Alicia's business. Alicia planned to use Iris's car as the lead vehicle in the wedding procession, driven by one of her staff members who had experience in handling luxury vehicles, though the exact details of who was to drive it had not been finalized at the time of Iris's death. Iris's car had been used for company events and representative purposes on several occasions besides the wedding, including business meetings and conferences, where it served as a symbol of the company's success and Iris's personal status.

"Detective Winston, we have new documents for you." An officer placed a file on his desk with a 'thump'. Financial statements. Alicia's business wasn't doing well. In fact, it was operating at a loss.

Heaving a sigh, Winston packed the files into his case. He made his way to Alicia's apartment. As he walked through the entrance, his gaze fell upon a ledge where the mail was neatly stacked. He could see a receipt peeping out. With a pair of thin gloves, he picked it up. A receipt from the shop. The same shop where Alicia was seen buying a stun gun.

He knew Alicia had studied electrical engineering during her college years. She would definitely know how to use it. His mobile device buzzed then, alerting him to a new email. It contained background info on Alicia's financials. A different kind of record... Alicia had been borrowing heavily, and mostly not from banks. Nontraditional lenders... not an ideal situation to be in.

Alicia provided an account of her activities on the day of the murder, stating she was busy with the final preparations for the wedding, including overseeing the setup and ensuring all vendors were in place, though she did admit to stepping away for about 30 minutes in the late afternoon to handle a personal matter, the details of which she was hesitant to discuss. There were inconsistencies in Alicia's alibi, particularly regarding the 30 minutes she claimed to have spent handling a personal matter, as one of the vendors reported seeing her near Iris's car around that time, though Alicia explained this away as a coincidence, stating she had merely been ensuring the car was in the correct position for the procession.

Stepping outside, Winston lit a cigarette, his hand steady, but mind racing. But then, his phone buzzed again with a new update from the precinct. There were multiple eyewitnesses who reported seeing Alicia and Iris together just before the incident. The last time they'd been seen together, was leaving the wedding rehearsal. The same evening when the incident happened. The police were able to obtain a list of all the guests and staff who attended the wedding rehearsal and the wedding itself, which included several individuals who had motive to harm Iris, including former business associates and acquaintances with whom Iris had had public disputes. Iris had several individuals who could be considered enemies due to her strict business dealings and refusal to compromise on certain projects, including a former business partner who had a public falling out with Iris a year prior to her death.

"Just the facts, Winston. Just the facts," he said to himself, squashing out the cigarette and returning inside. There was more to uncover, and Alicia just happened to be at the center of it

original_text.text:
In the heart of bustling Times Square, Johnny's life was abruptly ended with an unlikely weapon—a trident—and now, Detective Winston must unravel the murky truths hidden behind suspects Jay and Karl.

Winston peered at the case file and twitched his cigarette. Another one bit the dust in Times Square, a pretty common sight as of late. Jay, the regular local of the square, had made another one of his notorious catches, or so he seemed to be trying to. This time, however, it wasn't in the joy of celebration. 

Arresting the immediate crime scene routine, it came to an adoptive father. Jay, a man who loved his adopted son, Johnny, as deeply as his own blood. Unmistakably, he treated him with undying affection. Jay was a local fisherman, known to bait his lines and toss his nets in Times Square us with unusual regularity.

Winston was no stranger to the peculiar. A man making his catch amidst the solemn sea of humanity seemed alien yet plausible in ways nothing else could be. Winston lit another cigarette, his eyes tracing the hotel reservation confirmation in Jay’s name at a nearby hotel; Jay was also at Times Square for New Year's celebrations.

Now, that wasn’t unusual. After all, many locals booked rooms not far to be around the electric New Year’s celebration. Johnny, too, was part of the cacophony that night, showering in the confetti rain and the bursts of fireworks.

A cold shiver ran down Winston's spine as he recalled a conversation he had picked up where Jay overheard Johnny's intention to expose his illegal fishery.

The dynamics between a father and son duo is a complex bond. Johnny had officially registered himself under Jay’s guardianship quite a while ago, and now his disclosure had ignited an unexpected storm. 

Winston dropped his gaze onto the pictures of Jay's house. A noticeable collection caught his eyes. A vast array of tridents, carefully displayed and proudly shown off to any guest entering his abode. With an uneasiness settling over him, Winston noted that one of the tridents was strikingly similar to the weapon linked to Johnny's murder.

Winston took the last puff of his cigarette, and he ground the stub into the ashtray, turning over all the facts in his head. Already, the investigation looked murky, muddled with familial ties and sinister events.

Despite the rising sun casting long shadows, the path before Winston remained dark.

It was time to interview Jay, Winston decided, as he pieced together the intricate pattern connecting paternity, fishing, and a bloody murder.

Winston viewed the stark crime scene photos of Johnny's brutal murder in Times Square. The murder weapon was a trident, an oddity in any case, which only added to the eerie nature of Times Square, a place that seemed to attract all sorts of outlandish incidents.

His only solid lead so far was stock broker Karl, whom Johnny had been suspicious of. Karl was known to deal with more than just Wall Street, handling the financial investments of some of the most prominent celebrities. Well-known for his connections and unconventional tactics, it was rumored that he often used insider information for personal gain, a decidedly illegal maneuver on the stock market.

During their final showdown, Johnny had threatened to go to the police with evidence that pointed to Karl's crooked stock manipulations. But Johnny was brutally murdered before he could even do so. Now, as he viewed the images of Johnny's murder, Winston felt a deepening sense of dread.

It was time to question Karl. Upon arrival in the heart of Wall Street where Karl had his office, he found a bustling hub of blue suits. Amidst this flurry, Karl stood out, impeccably dressed and complete with a cordial smile he typically saved for his high-profile clients.

"Greetings, Detective," Karl said calmly.

"Good afternoon, Karl," Winston replied, keeping his tone neutral. "Can we have a moment to speak in private?"

In Karl's luxurious private office, an array of historical weapons adorned the walls, an unusual decorative taste for a corporate figure. Winston began the conversation stating the facts he already knew, "So you're a fan of historical weapons?"

"Not just a fan," Karl replied, putting on a proud smile, "Last summer, I even took lessons in trident fighting. It's all part of my personal life that I’d rather keep to myself. I’m not too fond of sharing personal information."

Upon digging deeper into Karl's dealings, Karl became visibly uncomfortable. His stiff body language indicated that he wasn't too keen on discussing his personal life further. Winston, however, continued to press on, bringing up Johnny and the documents he had left behind before his death - evidence of Karl's illegal stock manipulation.

Karl retained an impressively unflappable demeanor, revealing no hints of guilt or remorse. However, the mention of Johnny and the documents seemed to create a ripple in his stoic shell.

Then a call came to Winston's phone; it was his assistant informing him of the result of the search at Karl's house. Among the collection of historical artifacts and weapons, a trident was found - a chilling answer to the choice of murder weapon.

Confronting Karl with this latest discovery, Winston noticed a visible strain on Karl's face, his corporate mask slipping momentarily. After bidding him goodbye, Winston left the office, leaving a now silent Karl amongst his historical weapons and luxurious comforts. His passion for historical warfare had now become the primary focus of the murder investigation.

original_text.text:
In the heart of bustling Times Square, Johnny's life was abruptly ended with an unlikely weapon—a trident—and now, Detective Winston must unravel the murky truths hidden behind suspects Jay and Karl.

Winston immersed himself in the bustle of Times Square. The lights always seemed brighter after such a grim event. This used to be where Johnny, a legally adopted son of Jay, and Jay himself celebrated New Year's. However, tonight, their anticipated joint celebration was tarnished with tragedy. Jay was meant to accompany his son tonight, as he always did in previous years. Yet, today, the gaiety was marred by the spilt blood of young Johnny.

Taking silent inventory of the night's events, Winston departed Times Square and headed towards the residence of his unsuspecting suspect, Jay. He received curious glances from the neighbors as he passed by. His presence was quite striking given they were accustomed to seeing the irregular delivery trucks from far-flung places, implying Jay's suspected illegal fishery.

Reaching Jay's estate, Winston was greeted with a spectacle bizarre yet beautiful. Carefully arranged insects, like war trophies, were displayed for all. The place breathed less like an extermination spot and more like an entomologists’ gallery. In their conversation, Jay fervently talked of insects' idiosyncrasies reminiscing often about his entomology degree he pursued in college. It was a knowledge accumulated over the years, he claimed.

Despite such peculiar oddities, something else caught Winston’s attention. Jay's demeanor exhibited an aura of a grieving father who had just lost his child. Every word, every gesture towards Johnny was drenched in fatherly affection. This he observed as he subtly probed into Jay's Times Square hotel booking from that very night shared over their New Year's plans discussion.

Jay confidently produced the confirmation for his hotel reservation, confirming his presence at Times Square, booked for the very night of the murder taking place. He seemed unbothered, almost casual like discussing an ordinary routine, even when Johnny's intention to report his illegal fishery was disclosed. Winston found this revelation stirring. Johnny had confessed to him, and unbelievably, Jay happened to overhear their private conversation revealing Johnny's turn of trust.

The conversation took a turn towards Jay's unusual hobbies, including the exotic delivery trucks that catered to his needs, and the display cases filled with nicely arranged insects. Jay, light-hearted in his response, flirted with anecdotes trailing from his college days.

The air was thick with grief as they remembered Johnny. Loaded with information, Winston pieced together a clear perspective of the suspect. Yet the investigation was far from over. Something hung unanswered, unfinished. As Winston exited Jay's house, silence echoed the unspoken truths left to be discovered.

Winston scrutinized the surroundings of Times Square. It was almost surreal that amidst the clamor and hustle, a murder had taken place here, Johnny's murder. The murder weapon was peculiar, a trident.

Despite the city's innumerable faces, battalions of CCTV cameras, incessantly flashing screens surrounding the quadrant, a witness had spotted Karl here.

Clearing his throat, Winston began his interrogation. "You've been spotted here today Karl, can you explain that?"

The reply came quick, "Yeah, I was here, detective. I come here often."

"You and Johnny had an argument?"

"Yes," Karl nodded, then his face grew grave. "He threatened to go to the police about some documents he'd found. I tried to reason with him,” said Karl, his voice trembling slightly. “But we argued. We argued often. He had a hot temper, and I suspect, mad as hell he was."

People swarmed around like an ongoing carnival, but Winston kept his gaze unwavered on Karl. "You have a soft spot for history, don't you?" Winston ventured.

"Yeah, I love historical weaponry. I've got a nice collection at home," Karl stated somewhat proudly.

Winston knew, his suspicion was correct. The house search had revealed a Trident among Karl's collection of ancient weapons, now confiscated.

"Interesting," he observed. "Used any of them? For fighting or such."

"Tridents... I took some trident fighting lessons last summer," Karl admitted with an awkward laugh.

Strange coincidence, or just an indication of motives, Winston thought. Besides, the trident and Times Square; there was also that heated argument over some documents about his financial misdemeanors.

"Financial misdemeanors," Winston probed.

The look in Karl's eyes revealed something, but he simply shrugged, "Stock market’s a tricky business, detective. Johnny didn't fully understand it."

Winston thanked him for his time and left. City lights illuminated the square. Karl, now successful in stock manipulation, hoped to remain unseen by the police. But Johnny knew, and had discovered evidence of Karl’s illegal activities. Winston had a feeling, the city that never slept would soon reveal its hidden truths.

original_text.text:
In the tranquil world of pirouettes and pliés, prima ballerina Giselle is found dead with a syringe at a dance studio and it’s up to the steely-eyed Detective Winston to interrogate two unlikely suspects - Fred and Imogen.

Winston stared at the dance floor of the studio, reflecting on the horrific incident. Giselle, who had been practicing late in the night, was found in this one spot, a syringe sticking out. The studio was eerily quiet.

The security guard for the night, Fred, was now on the detective's radar. Guarding the studio, running its lost and found, working around the property, Fred had a significant hold on the location. Among his responsibilities was to ensure the items on the premises were secure. Recently, a syringe was reported misplaced and entered into the lost and found - the very syringe that, as per the Coroner's report, had been used in Giselle's murder.

Fred seemed more nervous than an employee should be given the circumstances. Scheduled to check properties during the time Giselle was practicing, he would have had the opportunity to interact with her. 

"Giselle...she was a hell of a dancer," Fred said, stepping away to look the dance floor. "Here late most nights, always the last to leave."

He hesitated before continuing, "She...she threatened to go to the authorities, about...about some things."

Fred's discomfort with the subject was evident. Giselle had found out about a few security lapses in the studio, and Fred was aware she had the evidence. She had threatened to report him, to show up his glaring disregard for the job he was responsible for.

Reflecting on the evidence, Winston looked at Fred. He was a night guard, in charge of property management. He had access to the studio, the found syringe, knowledge of Giselle's plans. He was more connected to the case than he probably would have liked.

Glancing back at the dance floor, Fred stared long and hard at the place where Giselle's body had been found. "I hear her sometimes, you know. The tap of her dance shoes. It's like she's still here."

Winston gave him a nod, made his notes before stepping out of the dance studio, leaving Fred alone with the haunting echo of Giselle's dance.

Winston shuffled the crime scene photos into a neat stack and replaced them in their folder. The image of the dance studio – clear aside from the single syringe lying in the centre – was fresh in his mind. He traced the edges of the file with a thoughtful brow and stood, straightening his jacket. The victim's godmother was waiting for him at her current workplace - the local hospital where she works as a nurse in her effort to pay off her debts, despite having lost her nursing job at a different hospital recently.

Imogen's life hadn't exactly gone according to plan. She used to be a respected nurse at another hospital, with a stable income, but now, despite her job at a new hospital, she was still struggling with severe debt, worsened by medical expenses she could hardly afford. One day, someone noticed Imogen with a set of keys that had been laying around the hospital. They were of a decidedly peculiar design, matching those from her former hospital. According to some people’s reports, they were similar to the ones used in prisons.

His first meeting was with Imogen herself. She was a middle-aged woman with worry lines that were etched deep into her face, a contrast from her professional demeanor at the hospital. Despite her situation, her eyes held a fierce spark of determination and resilience.

"Giselle was saving up for her future, you know," Imogen began, after the pleasantries were over. "She was a tenacious dancer, no children to her name, but wealthy nonetheless."

Winston asked about her relationship with Giselle, about her financial circumstances. Imogen was upfront about her financial issues, about how she had asked Giselle for help, despite being her godmother. She didn’t hide the fact that she had recently lost her job at the other hospital. 

Imogen shared a story about an escape plan she cooked up once. It was detailed and quite intricate, considering it was made up on the spot during a party. It was said in jest over drinks, but the detail of the plan was plausible to say the least.

Winston left the woman with a curt nod, wondering if Imogen’s elaborate plan was simply the ramblings of a desperate woman or perhaps, more than that. Her life, after all, had not worked out the way anyone would have hoped. And life, he knew, had a tendency of pushing people to do things they never thought they could.

original_text.text:
In the tranquil world of pirouettes and pliés, prima ballerina Giselle is found dead with a syringe at a dance studio and it’s up to the steely-eyed Detective Winston to interrogate two unlikely suspects - Fred and Imogen.

It was a typically bleak morning as detective Winston reflected on the upcoming staff meeting. No doubt Fred, the diligent night shift security guard for Dance Studio Giselle had devoted her life to, would again bring up the unsolved murder case. It was a habit of Fred to discuss the crime, be it casually or at a formal setting like the staff meetings.

Winston remembered Giselle mentioning Fred's constant references to the crime whenever they had personal interactions. Giselle's murder, occurring during a late-night practice at her dance studio when Fred was on his night shift, had flipped their world upside down, and now there was a whole list of strange occurrences. Fred had been caught, multiple times, brooding over his notebook scribbling details about the various events. Not just during his nightly shifts, but meticulously recording the date, time, and details of each recent crime that took place in and around the dance studio.

Winston often wondered about the contents of Fred's notebook. He recalled Fred having overheard a personal conversation between Giselle and himself when she had openly voiced her plans to bring her findings about his security lapses to the authorities. It was strange how quickly Fred had been informed about it, almost as if he had intentionally been listening in.

Slowly sipping his coffee, Winston made his way to Fred’s space, hearing the familiar scratch of Fred’s pen against paper. Fred, tall with broad shoulders and a hard-set face, looked up, his pen momentarily idle.

Fred, never one to skip over details, asked, as if on cue, "Detective, any updates about the murder?"

"Fred," Winston carefully started, acknowledging his inquiry. "Yes, updates about Giselle's claim of finding evidence against your nighttime security practices and her plan of taking it to the authorities. You knew about it, didn't you?"

Fred chuckled nervously and looked down at his notebook, his eyes lingering on his detailed crime records. Nodding, he softly confessed, "Yes, I overheard her talking about it. Couldn't help but worry, detective."

Intent on keeping a keen eye on each detail, detective Winston left Fred back to recounting the happenings in his notebook, knowing there were a lot more facts to align in this perplexing puzzle.

Winston assembled his notes and drained his mug of lukewarm coffee. He turned his thoughts to Giselle, the victim. From all accounts she was a wealthy ballerina, well-loved in the community, rarely seen without a crowd applauding her every move. She had no children, but was known to be frugal, having long been building a nest egg for an ambitious future. He grimaced. The future was one thing she no longer had.

His next stop was at a bustling hospital. His entrance was marked by the characteristic smell of disinfectant and the chaos of emergency medical staff rushing about. Among them, he used to find Imogen, a former nurse who likely felt comfortable amidst the syringes, gloves and pill bottles. Imogen had worked there long enough to cultivate a reliable reputation, until her recent dismissal. Winston had been notified about her job loss by a hospital insider.

After the hospital, detective Winston drove to Imogen's house. Imogen was Giselle’s godmother, and they shared a close bond, so close that Giselle confided in her like no other. Imogen was among the few who knew about Giselle’s financial prudence as she saved for the future. Giselle treated Imogen like a member of her own family, even extending an implicit trust to her. She invited Imogen to her performances and elite parties frequently, detective Winston noted a stack of fancy invitations on Imogen's side table. 

With the pleasantries out of the way, the detective carefully broached the subject of Imogen’s financial struggles. He had discovered that Imogen had some rather sizable medical bills to pay. These bills burdened her with a severe debt. This was no small sum to be owing, especially after losing her job.

“You asked for financial help from Giselle, didn't you?” he asked, choosing his words carefully. Imogen looked away, nodding and admitting,"Yes, losing my job was a shock. I asked her for help."

Winston could tell this wasn’t an easy admission for Imogen, her goddaughter’s death compounded by the guilt of asking for financial help. As their conversation came to an end, Winston thanked her for cooperation and walked back to his car. 

No conclusions had been drawn. No suspects had been named, but the information gathered from Imogen was another piece in a complex puzzle. The very picture of a detective's work. A bottomless mug of coffee, a relentless quest for answers... and a lingering smell of hospital disinfectant.

Inside the buzzing hubbub of the city's most popular recording studio, Ivan's death by snake venom sends shockwaves through the music realm, forcing the indomitable Detective Winston to pierce the veil of sound and silence, suspects, Timothy and Ricky, echoing in his ears.

The buzzing audio equipment of the recording studio filled the eerie silence as Winston took in the place where Ivan's life had tragically ended. The coroner's report indicated Ivan's time of death aligns perfectly with when Timothy, a self-professed herpetology enthusiast with extensive knowledge of acquiring and handling venom from his exotic snakes, had been at the studio. It had only been a few days, but the studio felt hauntingly empty. He turned his gaze to the padded wall, where someone had written, "Timothy and Ivan, a deadly harmony."

It was here that Winston found a recorded conversation between Ivan and Timothy, where Ivan fiercely confronted Timothy about his secret affair with Ivan's girlfriend. "You'll have hell to pay," Ivan had threatened in the recording. Clearly, Ivan was no longer a mere obstacle for Timothy, but a threat to his secret relationship that he wouldn't afford to get exposed.

Back at headquarters, Winston found himself faced with Timothy in the interrogation room, a lanky lad with a laid-back demeanor of a surfing instructor. "So, Timothy," began Winston trying to cut through the tension. "You were at the recording studio on the day Ivan died, right?"

"Yeah..." Timothy played with the frayed edge of his board shorts, "We were working on a music project, you know. I just... I had no idea he was gonna end up... like that."

"And no one else was at the studio then, I assume?" Winston questioned calmly. Timothy merely nodded, his gaze fixed on the plain metal table between them.

Winston pursued, "I heard... something about Ivan confronting you about your secret affair with his girlfriend. That'd make anyone pretty jealous. And then you'd be afraid Ivan would reveal your secret, right?" Silence followed as Timothy clenched his jaw tightly, hands nervously tightening into fists. His jealousy was evident, as was his fear of Ivan revealing their secret relationship.

Later that day, Winston found himself wandering down to a strange, exotic animal shop in the city. The shopkeeper, a wiry man with spectacles, recognized Timothy from a photograph. Timothy frequented the place, purchasing his exotic snakes from here - not just for their beauty but also for the lethal venom some of them could produce.

"They're beautiful creatures," the shopkeeper remarked, "Can be really dangerous though. Timothy knows that. He spends hours studying them and knows exactly how to handle them and their venom."

Winston nodded, thoughts racing in his mind. The timeline was starting to line up... Ivan confronted Timothy about his affair with his girlfriend, resulting in Timothy becoming jealous. With his advanced knowledge of venom and snakes, Timothy could have easily silenced Ivan forever. As he walked out of the store, Winston looked back at the snakes. Their eyes gleamed ominously under the warm lights, a dangerous secret they shared with their owner.

Detective Winston stared at the envelope in his hands. It contained a recording of a man's voice... Ricky's voice. Ricky had confessed to engaging in illegal activities at the pet shop he owned during a one-on-one meeting with Ivan, an incriminating evidence towards Ricky. Ivan, Ricky's employee, had managed to record this meeting and now was using it to blackmail his boss. Ivan was the sole possessor of such damning evidence against Ricky. The envelope addressed to Ivan had been found amongst the many other envelopes from anonymous senders that overloaded Ricky's mail box daily. Winston sighed, mentally checking off the initial facts.

Stepping inside the pet shop, Winston noted Ricky, the man who was visibly apprehensive. He was holding onto something, something that spelled danger. Ricky owned a venomous snake- his trusted companion. Winston's eyes narrowed visibly, remembering Ricky's well-versed knowledge of venom extraction. But right now, his attention was more focused on the legal documents that lay strewn about the table. The pet shop was in his name, and the blackmail was threatening ruin, both financially and legally.

Suddenly, Ricky moved. He pulled open a drawer bursting with wigs, glasses, and an assortment of props. Instantly, Winston recalled the photograph he received from a witness, who had spotted Ricky at a passport photo shop. The picture showed Ricky surrounded by various props, similar to the ones he now held in his hands. Ricky seemed to be prepared for every eventuality, but why? Winston kept his thoughts to himself, focusing on the task at hand.

Ricky moved around the room, apparently agitated. Winston asked him mundane questions, like how his day had been, what his work involved. Ricky, nervous though he was, responded readily. Soon, minutes turned into hours as the detective–suspect duo sat locked in an interrogation that was as much unspoken as spoken. The room still held the echo of Ivan's lethal poisoning, and with each word uttered, Ricky painted a complex canvas; a canvas depicting a secretive life of illegal activities, desperate actions, and an existence losing coherence amidst the deceit.

Winston knew, the mystery was far from solved. There were still layers to Ricky that needed to be peeled back. He knew he had a tough task ahead with numerous clues left to be discovered. As he exited the pet shop door, he bade farewell to a day filled with questioning and welcomed an impending journey of uncloaking the truth.

original_text.text:
Inside the buzzing hubbub of the city's most popular recording studio, Ivan's death by snake venom sends shockwaves through the music realm, forcing the indomitable Detective Winston to pierce the veil of sound and silence, suspects, Timothy and Ricky, echoing in his ears.

The flashing lights and the police tape painted a macabre picture outside the recording studio where Ivan was pronounced dead. Detective Winston stared at the dispatch report and heaved a weary sigh. Highlighted information spelled out a sad tale of love, jealousy, and secrets; especially the ones contained in Timothy's silent confession of an argument where Ivan confronted him about the affair with his girlfriend.

As he entered the studio, a peculiar detail stood out – it was empty when the victim was found. The police had taken the usual preliminary measures, clearing the premises as they went. That detail played a repetitive note in Winston's mind. There was only one name that matched the time of death, Timothy.

Begrudgingly, he agreed to interview Timothy, the victim’s friend and also a surfing instructor by trade. Timothy's van was a shrine to waxed boards of all sizes, shapes, and colors, almost like weapons of battle against the waves. When Winston had asked him about it, Timothy fondly explained that every board had its unique purpose, for each wave and beach condition. His job demanded him to know places, waves, and beaches in intimate detail. One could even notice the envy tinged bitterness in Timothy's voice when he shared his love for discovering new surfing spots and how Ivan’s musical success overshadowed his own aspirations.

“What brings you here, detective?” Timothy's voice cut through Winston's thoughts. “Well, you were last seen here with Ivan. You guys…"

“Yeah, we were working on a music project together,” Timothy finished Winston's half-spoken question. His face turned a shade darker as he added, “That was our thing, you know. He did the music, I brought the vibe. But everyone always loved Ivan more, even my own girlfriend.”

There was a certain restlessness in Timothy's manner. His eyes kept darting towards the door, his van in sight. It was always packed and ready; 'to chase the waves,' Timothy had shared during the friendly chit-chat. His resentment towards Ivan had resurfaced, amplified by the fact that Ivan's girlfriend was now in love with him.

When Winston mentioned Ivan's girlfriend, Timothy's smile tightened. Yet when he asked about the argument where Ivan had confronted him about the affair, the smile faded away completely. He didn't want to expose sharper edges of their relationship; the complex, fraught friendship woven with threads of rivalry and jealousy. Most of all, there was a looming fear of Ivan revealing their secret affair to the world.

Winston slowly stood up, giving Timothy a knowing look. He thanked him for his time and walked away, leaving an unsettling silence behind him as Timothy sat, staring at the spot where Ivan used to create music. His secret was a festering wound he had no idea how to treat, and the fear of exposure was a haunting melody he couldn't escape.

At the end of a long day, Winston found himself standing on the bridge, gazing at the dark and unyielding ocean. The carefully collected facts played on repeat, like a song stuck in a loop. He couldn't help but think of Timothy, his passions, his secrets, his fear, his jealousy, and his time at the studio which eerily aligned with the irrevocable end of Ivan's life. A hazy picture began to take form in his mind, but he knew it was far from complete...There were still missing notes in this haunting symphony of death.

Detective Winston stepped out of his car and straightened his tie as he made his way towards the pet shop. An older man stood at the entrance, a look of potential fear and regret on his face. 

"Ricky?" Winston asked with a raised eyebrow.

"Depends who's asking," Ricky responded, eyeing Winston over. 

"Detective Winston," he introduced himself and showed his badge. He noticed a change in Ricky's demeanor. "Might we have a word regarding your business?"

Ricky, swallowing hard, nodded and gestured to the back room of the pet shop. It was filled with a variety of animals, among them a large, intimidating venomous snake settled in a glass tank, aptly showcased as the shop's specialty.

"You seem to have quite a variety of pets here, and appropriate paperwork on display. You do legally own this place, don't you?" Winston asked, pointing at the legal documents hanging on the wall.

Ricky, still unsettled, nodded, "Yes. I also know a bit about venom extraction, which makes this business unique," he added with an attempt at lightheartedness. 

"You know, the police got a tip-off about some illegal activity regarding this pet shop," Winston continued. Ricky's eyes widened.

"Why, I've no idea what you're insinuating detective," Ricky stuttered, looking like a man who feared impending financial and legal repercussions.

"Your financial situation hasn't been the best we've heard," Winston said, "and someone named Ivan has been feeding us some rather interesting information regarding your debts."

"Ivan." Ricky whispered under his breath.

"It seems you had a private meeting with Ivan in an empty recording studio," Winston revealed, seeing Ricky's surprise at this information. "That's where he recorded your conversation, and you confessed to some illegal activities, didn't you?"

Ricky looked down and then glanced up, resignation in his eyes. He nodded somberly, "Yes, Ivan was the only one who knew about the illegal activities... He recorded me talking about the illegal sales and has been blackmailing me with the recording."

Winston thanked Ricky for his time and walked out of the pet shop with much to ponder about this case. One thing was certain - the recording studio where Ricky made his confession was going to be his next stop.

original_text.text:
In the glitzy, high-stakes world of casinos, Jamal meets a deadly end by frog poison, leaving Detective Winston to weave through a web of deceit with two prime suspects - Kimberly and Lillian.

Winston stood somberly over the roulette table, the stilled wheel now a chilling reminder of the danger that lay in the house's favor. Jamal's empty chair, a token of a dangerous gamble. Too high of a stake, with a godchild as your appointed dealer.

"Lillian, was it?" Winston began, attempting to keep his tone as neutral as possible. The woman before him, a young biologist specializing in amphibians, nodded as she squirmed slightly under his gaze.

"Jamal spoke highly of you," he said, casting an eye towards her drink. She gulped, but stayed silent.

"He trusted you," Winston continued, surveying the crime scene with his trained eye. "Even was seen taking a sip from your very drink there."

Lillian straightened in her chair. "Always giving him advice," Winston mused, a thought dancing at the edge of his vision. "And always willing to try something new."

It wasn't hard to guess that Lillian had always desired more. The lust for power hung around her like an exotic perfume, intoxicating to those in her proximity. She wanted to be Jamal. Jamal, the casino mogul; his elusive empire tantalizingly within reach.

Outside, the neon lights of the casino blinked erratically, casting an eerie greenish hue over the scene. A darting shadow caught Winston's attention - a strange silhouette of a rare species of frog in a glass tank, well-known amongst biologists for its lethal toxins, shimmered in the glow. An interesting pet for a woman so consumed with desire.

"Lillian, you're a herpetologist, we gather?" Winston questioned, inclining his head towards the amphibian. She nodded, a glint appearing in her eyes. "And you've been studying the toxins of this frog for years..."

Dismissing Lillian, Winston surveyed the casino once more. It was a den of decadence, a palace of transient prosperity run by Jamal, the giver of fortunes, who had no other known kin but a science-smitten child drawn to the perilous allure of her amphibian pets.

One clear fact remained. Jamal had listened to Lillian and she... well, she was next in line for his throne. This was not a conjecture but a simple fact an observer might note, just as one might notice the inescapable presence of a rare poison frog in Lillian's possession.

As Winston made his exit from the pulsating hub of the casino, his mind turned over the night's events. Lillian, pacing the casino floor, her eyes on Jamal, and Jamal's undying trust in his favored godchild. Pieces of a puzzle waiting to be fit together. But that, he left strictly for the reader to sort out.

As Winston strolled through the garish neon lights of the casino, he watched the footage replay on the manager's phone. There they were, tucked into the high stake section; Kimberly, a picture-perfect shuffle of a grandma, and Jamal, joyfully throwing himself into the game with wild abandon.

"Yes," the manager confirmed for him. "That’s Kimberly. Her card records place her at the same table as Jamal that night. She didn't leave until the medics arrived for him."

"Interesting," Winston replied, still not looking up from the phone.

The detective continued his rounds, shuffling further into the labyrinth of the casino. Finally, he found the bar. He nodded at the barman, an inquisitive look in his eyes. "Kimberly brought Jamal a drink that night, didn’t she?"

The barman swiped at an imaginary spill as he raised an eyebrow at Winston. "Yeah, she did. One of those fancy drinks." His fingers drummed thoughtfully on the bartop, "She had it delivered to the table he was playing at. He drank it right away too."

Another loose thread to tuck away, perhaps. Winston next stop was Kimberly's house. Neighbors echoed praises about the grandmother, painting her as a caring woman who enjoys watching her grandchildren. Interestingly enough, each grandchild seemed to know her by a different name, and according to the school records, each had a distinct backstory of ‘grandma Kimberly’.

Winston cradled a cup of coffee as he glanced through Kimberly's research papers. Geological, biological, a vast array of topics. But one caught his eye; a detailed study on various poisons, including how much was lethal. Of particular interest was one paper detailing the extraction methods for poison from a highly dangerous frog species.

Flipping through her mail, each letter addressed to a unique mailing address, one for each city Kimberly had grandchildren. Winston noticed the faint hum of an odd contraption in her basement. Upon closer inspection, it was an ornate humidifier. Sitting inside a glass tank, a small frog, the same species she had written about.

"Got yourself a pet frog, Kimberly?" Winston asked, blinking back a sense of unease.  

"Well, yes, I thought it'd be fascinating to own one," Kimberly answered, her voice steady yet pleasant. "After buying it, I've done a lot of reading on it too."

“I can tell,” Winston said, lightly tapping at the glass, his gaze looking upon the venomous creature inside, through the misty veil, before flicking over at Kimberly for a brief moment, "I can tell."

Lillian and Jamal's business relationship was that of mentor and protégée, with Jamal guiding Lillian in her efforts to expand her amphibian-themed business ventures, including a proposed chain of exotic pet stores.

Lillian straightened in her chair. "Always giving him advice," Winston mused, a thought dancing at the edge of his vision. "And always willing to try something new." It wasn't hard to guess that Lillian had always desired more. The lust for power hung around her like an exotic perfume, intoxicating to those in her proximity. She wanted to be Jamal. Jamal, the casino mogul; his elusive empire tantalizingly within reach. Jamal had several known rivals in the casino business, including a notorious underworld figure who had been trying to muscle in on Jamal's territory, though Detective Winston was unsure if this had any direct connection to the murder.

Outside, the neon lights of the casino blinked erratically, casting an eerie greenish hue over the scene. A darting shadow caught Winston's attention - a strange silhouette of a rare species of frog in a glass tank, well-known amongst biologists for its lethal toxins, shimmered in the glow. An interesting pet for a woman so consumed with desire. "Lillian, you're a herpetologist, we gather?" Winston questioned, inclining his head towards the amphibian. She nodded, a glint appearing in her eyes. "And you've been studying the toxins of this frog for years..." Several individuals had access to the rare species of frog in Lillian's possession, including her business partners, employees, and even some of her acquaintances, though Lillian assured Detective Winston that she kept the frog in a secure, locked enclosure at all times.

Dismissing Lillian, Winston surveyed the casino once more. It was a den of decadence, a palace of transient prosperity run by Jamal, the giver of fortunes, who had no other known kin but a science-smitten child drawn to the perilous allure of her amphibian pets. One clear fact remained. Jamal had listened to Lillian and she... well, she was next in line for his throne. This was not a conjecture but a simple fact an observer might note, just as one might notice the inescapable presence of a rare poison frog in Lillian's possession. Lillian's story and behavior did raise some suspicions, particularly her inconsistent alibi and her apparent lack of emotion when discussing Jamal's death, though Detective Winston was unsure if this was simply a result of her tough business persona. Lillian did have some financial troubles, having invested heavily in her business ventures and being deeply in debt, though she assured Detective Winston that she was on the verge of a major breakthrough and would soon be financially stable.

As Winston made his exit from the pulsating hub of the casino, his mind turned over the night's events. Lillian, pacing the casino floor, her eyes on Jamal, and Jamal's undying trust in his favored godchild. Pieces of a puzzle waiting to be fit together. But that, he left strictly for the reader to sort out. As Winston strolled through the garish neon lights of the casino, he watched the footage replay on the manager's phone. There they were, tucked into the high stake section; Kimberly, a picture-perfect shuffle of a grandma, and Jamal, joyfully throwing himself into the game with wild abandon. Kimberly had met Jamal on several occasions prior to the night of the murder, having played at his casino multiple times and even participated in a few high-stakes tournaments, though their interactions were always brief and professional.

"Yes," the manager confirmed for him. "That’s Kimberly. Her card records place her at the same table as Jamal that night. She didn't leave until the medics arrived for him." "Interesting," Winston replied, still not looking up from the phone. The composition of the drink that Kimberly brought to Jamal included a mix of exotic liqueurs and a splash of fruit juice, with the poison being expertly disguised as a harmless ingredient, later revealed to be a highly concentrated extract of the rare frog's toxin. Unfortunately, the security cameras did not capture the exact moment the poison was administered, as the footage was obscured by a brief power outage caused by a faulty wire, which was later deemed to be an unfortunate coincidence.

The detective continued his rounds, shuffling further into the labyrinth of the casino. Finally, he found the bar. He nodded at the barman, an inquisitive look in his eyes. "Kimberly brought Jamal a drink that night, didn’t she?" The barman swiped at an imaginary spill as he raised an eyebrow at Winston. "Yeah, she did. One of those fancy drinks." His fingers drummed thoughtfully on the bartop, "She had it delivered to the table he was playing at. He drank it right away too." The barman knew that Kimberly had brought Jamal a drink because he had seen her order it at the bar and then deliver it to Jamal's table, though he did not see her prepare the drink itself, having been busy serving other customers at the time.

Another loose thread to tuck away, perhaps. Winston's next stop was Kimberly's house. Neighbors echoed praises about the grandmother, painting her as a caring woman who enjoys watching her grandchildren. Interestingly enough, each grandchild seemed to know her by a different name, and according to the school records, each had a distinct backstory of ‘grandma Kimberly’. Kimberly's grandchildren were unaware of her involvement with the casino or Jamal, having been told that she was simply a retired teacher who enjoyed playing cards and traveling. The different names and backstories that Kimberly's grandchildren had for her were a result of her complex and secretive past, with Kimberly having assumed multiple identities over the years to protect herself and her loved ones from her previous life.

Winston cradled a cup of coffee as he glanced through Kimberly's research papers. Geological, biological, a vast array of topics. But one caught his eye; a detailed study on various poisons, including how much was lethal. Of particular interest was one paper detailing the extraction methods for poison from a highly dangerous frog species. Kimberly acquired the poison frog and the knowledge to extract its toxins through her extensive research and networking with other herpetologists and biologists, having become fascinated with the species after reading about its unique characteristics.

Flipping through her mail, each letter addressed to a unique mailing address, one for each city Kimberly had grandchildren. Winston noticed the faint hum of an odd contraption in her basement. Upon closer inspection, it was an ornate humidifier. Sitting inside a glass tank, a small frog, the same species she had written about. "Got yourself a pet frog, Kimberly?" Winston asked, blinking back a sense of unease. "Well, yes, I thought it'd be fascinating to own one," Kimberly answered, her voice steady yet pleasant. "After buying it, I've done a lot of reading on it too." “I can tell,” Winston said, lightly tapping at the glass, his gaze looking upon the venomous creature inside, through the misty veil, before flicking over at Kimberly for a brief moment, "I can tell."

The procedure for handling and storing the poison frog in Lillian's care involved keeping it in a secure, climate-controlled enclosure with multiple safety protocols in place, including warning signs, protective gear, and emergency procedures in case of an escape or accident. The casino had several security measures in place to prevent the use of poison or other harmful substances on the premises, including surveillance cameras, security personnel, and regular sweeps for toxic materials, though these measures had apparently failed to prevent Jamal's murder. Several other individuals had motives to kill Jamal, including his business rivals, disgruntled employees, and even some of his own family members, though Detective Winston was unsure if any of these individuals had the means or opportunity to commit the crime. Jamal's trust in Lillian was unwavering, with him often seeking her counsel on business matters and even considering her as a potential successor, though he did have some reservations about her ambition and willingness to take risks. Detective Winston became aware of the rare poison frog and its connection to the murder through his initial investigation and interviews with Lillian and Kimberly, having discovered that both women had a fascination with the species and its unique toxins. Lillian claimed to have been in the casino's VIP lounge, socializing with other high-rollers, from 10 PM until Jamal's death, though her alibi was shaky at best, with several witnesses reporting that she had stepped out for a few minutes around 11:30 PM.

original_text.text:
In the glitzy, high-stakes world of casinos, Jamal meets a deadly end by frog poison, leaving Detective Winston to weave through a web of deceit with two prime suspects - Kimberly and Lillian.

Winston took a moment to steady his thoughts as he pushed through the bustling casino crowd and headed towards the high stakes tables, where the Kurten family, a notable name in the city that Kimberly Kurten was always so intensely proud of, often gathered.

In his possession, he had copies of the casino’s surveillance footage, which clearly showed Kimberly not leaving the casino until after the events of the tragic night had unraveled. It was indeed an unusual evening, where he had gained knowledge that Jamal was about to reveal his secret gambling problem, a scandal that could have undoubtedly ruined the reputation of the Kurten family, before his tragic death ended those plans untimely.

Winston found Kimberly, Jamal's grandmother, sitting sullenly with a spent slot machine, her eyes tired and glassy. She was always a lady of resolve, and her attire tonight attested her character. The familiar cigarette smoke-infused air around her gave gravity to the situation.

"We heard you've been interested in studying unique frog species," Winston started tentatively, referencing her recent purchase of a rare and highly poisonous frog, without failing to mention about the documents found in her home, which not only discussed extracting venom from the said species but also comprehensively detailed physical effects of the frog's lethal doses,

"Yes," Kimberly admitted. "It's quite a fascinating hobby that I've picked up."

"Do you know the frog you own can be highly lethal?" Winston probed, watching her reaction closely.

"Well, I am aware. In fact, I've read all about it, and that formed a substantial part of my research, especially investigating the effects of its venom," said Kimberly, revealing her ongoing project for the first time.

Nodding, Winston changed the subject. "You were with Jamal here at the casino, the night he tragically died, correct?"

"Yes," she said softly, her voice barely audible over the chorus of slot machines and croupier calls. "We both came here together."

"On the surveillance footage, it appears you brought Jamal his favorite drink that night. Barely a few moments after he had it, he collapsed."

"Yes, that's correct, Detective Winston," Kimberly confirmed, her gaze fixed somewhere distant, "He wasn't feeling well all evening. I've always been worried about his reckless gambling, and the impact it would have on our standing in society, not to mention the ruin it would have brought upon us if he had his way."

After a few moments of silence, Winston rose to excuse himself, leaving Kimberly dwelling in the harsh neon lights, weighed down by a grandmother's sorrow. Despite the clamoring commotion around him, Winston found an eerie silence; a tragic tale of love, concern, and reputation had unraveled that night.

Sitting in his criminally underlit office, Detective Winston pored over the case files for Jamal's murder. His brow furrowed at the cause of death - a lethal frog poison. The corners of his mouth twitched with a hint of moroseness and intrigue, as he thought of the exotic demise of a man so influential and with no known heirs or successors - except his goddaughter Lillian.

Winston decided to pay Lillian, the goddaughter of the deceased, a visit. He remembered the name Lillian, an up-and-coming biologist specializing in amphibians, and now the apparent successor to Jamal's influential position — a coincidence too striking to ignore.

On arriving at Lillian's residence, he knocked and was greeted by Lillian's younger brother, who he had noticed earlier mentioned a strict 9 p.m. curfew enforced by their parents — a prospect seeming unusual considering Lillian's mature age.

"Detective Winston, how can I help you?" Lillian's voice was calm. Winston, with practiced ease, began to ask the routine questions.

"I understand from your colleagues at the research facility that you have spent years studying the toxins of various rare frog species. That's remarkable."

"Yes, I believe amphibians are hugely underestimated in their biological significance," Lillian responded, an earnest enthusiasm glowing in her eyes.

Her comment whisked Winston's thoughts back to the exotic murder weapon. "Are there any of such poisonous species that you happen to own?"

A slight hitch in Lillian's demeanor suggested hesitation. "Yes, I do own a rare species of frog known to produce lethal toxins."

Leaning back and taking note of her demeanor, Winston changed the topic slightly. "Did you know about the late-night visits Jamal used to pay to the casino?"

"No, but I knew of his influence and power in the community," Lillian replied, her eyes distant as she pondered over memories of her late godfather. She further added, "Jamal didn't have any other known successors and being his goddaughter, I've always desired to be as respected and influential as he was, and to even take his position one day."

As Winston prepared to leave, the local store owner from across the street approached him, offering a piece of information he hadn't considered.

"Saw Lillian over there popping out late for snacks," he mumbled; a detail that contradicted the household rule of strict curfew mentioned by Lillian's brother. It was backed up by another neighbor, who mentioned seeing Lillian sneaking out after dark on numerous occasions.

It appeared there was more to this goddaughter, this aspiring biologist, than met the eye. This next in line to Jamal's influence and authority, known herpetologist, owner of a lethal frog species– was she just an innocent bystander? Winston intended to find out.
